events.name: Pre-BLACKHAT Skill-up Seminar
events.description:
With the vast information ongoing during the Black Hat Asia conference, we feels that pre-conference preparation is important to enhance your conference experience.  A pre-BlackHat preparation has been always in the mind-set for most Black Hat attendees; “ if I only have to research more on the topics, I would be able to have a greater discussion with the speakers ……”  Therefore, IPv6 Forum (Singapore Chapter) will be hosting a half day Pre-Conference skill-up seminar which aims to help prior to Black Hat Asia 2016.  In this seminar, we would aid the conference attendees to prepare and stay abreast of the latest knowledge in the constantly evolving cyber security industry. We are inviting cyber professionals to share on the latest information and to debate topics critical to cyber security. 


Agenda 9.00amRegistration 9.30amWelcome Speech 9.45am – 10.15amUpdate and Skill-Up before BLACKHAT ConferenceSpeaker: Mr Robert L. Arquiza, Trainer and Consultant, Worldtech Information Solutions, Inc. Those in the IT world are always looking to develop the right skill sets that will help them get noticed above their competition. Considering how quickly technology changes, possessing a highly-desired set of skills can lead to better jobs. The Skills that needs to look at the threat landscape is ever-changing, and so are the skills that are needed to mitigate them. In this presentation, we will weigh in on some of the most in-demand skill sets needed in the security industry today. 10.15am – 11.00amCritical Infra-structure: Cyber Attack Vulnerability TestSpeaker: Mr Ken Soh, CEO, Athena Dynamics As we know cyber attack today are unlike the past. It is stealthful, silent, hard to detect and yet fatal. Worse, today, many of such attacks are turning their targets from just PCs to critical infra-structures like vessels, oil rigs, energy, water and nuclear plants.Many anti-malware today are failing as they could not cope with the rapid advancement of attack techniques and viruses. We need a more strategic approach and stronger tools to counter them. One of the key starting points is to perform professional assessment of the vulnerability of systems. 11.00am – 11.30amBreak 11.30am – 12.15pmIOT Security - Do you know you have a backdoor in your smart devices?Speaker: Mr Robert L. Arquiza, Trainer and Consultant, Worldtech Information Solutions, Inc. Twenty years ago, if you told me my phone could be used to steal the password to my email account or to take a copy of my fingerprint data, I would’ve laughed at you and said you watch too much James Bond. But today, if you tell me that hackers with malicious intents can use my toaster to break into my Facebook account, I will panic and quickly pull the plug from the evil appliance.Welcome to the era of the Internet of Things (IoT), where digitally connected devices are encroaching on every aspect of our lives, including our homes, offices, cars and even our bodies. With the advent of IPv6 and the wide deployment of Wi-Fi networks, IoT is growing at a dangerously fast pace, and researchers estimate that by 2020, the number of active wireless connected devices will exceed 40 billion. The Question is are we ready for the World of Security, IOT? 12.15pm – 12.30pmQ&A / Closing Please register at: http://www.eventbrite.sg/e/pre-blackhat-skill-up-seminar-registration-21711456551
events.location: 8 Wilkie Road, Level 2, Wilkie Edge, Room: WE218, 219, Singapore

events.name: How does the public sector adopt open standards & FLOSS, Norvan Vogt, Health AU
events.description:
Learn about the adoption of open standards and FLOS Software in the public sector from Norvan Vogt through his experience at Queensland Health in Australia. This workshop takes place at FOSSASIA in the track "Internet, Society, Community" at the Science Centre Singapore. Location: Level 2, Einstein Room 


Participation Tickets are available here: http://www.eventnook.com/event/fossasia/register Daily tickets cost 7 SGD. Website: http://2016.fossasia.org Workshop of 1 hour Organisational budgets are shrinking and stakeholders are putting increasing pressure on public sector organisations to be efficient without jeopardising service delivery. There is a multitude of ways to share and reuse software amongst organisations and the public sector employs (and has employed) a variety of different approaches. This session will specifically focus on open source software and the factors influencing the adoption of open source software within public sector organisations. The primary objective of the session is to explore open source software benefits for public sector organisations, discuss the current state of adoption, and review the motivators and a-motivators affecting adoption. A secondary objective of the session is to investigate where organisations are utilising open source software and whether organisations consider open source software as a means of achieving business goals. 


About Norvan Vogt: Norvan is passionate about open source technology and using ICT to make a difference in the world. At age 18, Norvan co-founded an open source software company in Canberra. In 2004, he was responsible for leading the campaign that concluded with the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) legislative assembly changing legislation, where they are preferencing open source software during procurement. Furthermore, Norvan has spent at least five years working internationally on ICT projects, creating open source solutions through community development methodologies, for the United Nations, AusAID and the World Bank, in Vanuatu, Cambodia and Guatemala. Norvan has served in a range of high level advisory roles, such as the Prime Minister’s Youth Roundtable, Defence Reserves Support Council and the United Nations International Symposium on Volunteering. He is currently employed by Townsville Hospital as the Chief Information Officer for the health district and is also studying a PhD part-time at James Cook University.  Web  LinkedIn
events.location: Science Centre Singapore, Einstein Room (Level 2), 15 Science Centre Road, 609081 Singapore

events.name: Friday Hacks #110 - Robust, scalable, and secure mobile apps in hostile environments.
events.description:
For our sixth Friday Hacks of the semester, we’re having Jordan Dea-Mattson speak about Wobe’s system architecture and how it uniquely addresses the issues of building robust, scalable, and secure mobile applications in hostile environments.

Talk Description:

The Wobe system architecture is designed to work in environments with highly unreliable network access. In fact, it assumes a poor network and accounts it from day one.

The Wobe architecture is asynchronous and event/message based vs. the more common synchronous architectures. It’s comprised of a mobile client for Android and a collection of microservices developed in Go. It’s designed to work in high latency, low bandwidth environments and poor reliability network access.

In addition, Jordan will be sharing Wobe’s plans for open sourcing significant components of its architecture to help others adopt a better mobile services architecture. If you are looking for an interesting, approachable, challenging open source to contribute to, this is your chance to learn more.

Speaker Profile

Jordan Dea-Mattson (https://www.linkedin.com/in/jordandeamattson) is a 30+ veteran of HighTech with most of that time spent working in Silicon Valley. Jordan has worked at Apple (13 years), Adobe Systems, Ooyala, and Yahoo among other companies.

Jordan has spent his career focused on efficiently and effectively building and delivering high quality software and enabling others to do so as well.

Jordan has spoken at numerous industry events, including Apple’s WWDC (12 straight years), Atlassian’s Summit, and ChefConf.

Company Profile

Wobe (http://wobe.io) founded by long-time Singapore and South East Asia innovator and entrepreneur, Adrianna Tan, delivers a brand new take on financial services to the underserved — low income women in emerging markets.

Through their app, young urban and rural entrepreneurs can start small businesses: they can resell phone airtime and other pre-paid goods and services to their friends and family. Most Wobe agents will be able to easily increase their family income by $US 10 a day, moving them solidly into the emerging middle class.


Free pizzas as usual!

More information here: http://nushackers.org/2016/03/friday-hacks-110-Mar-18

Our Sponsors

Friday Hacks is sponsored by the NUS Enterprise Center.

If you are looking to turn your ideas into a startup and would love some business support, feel free to get in touch with Agustiadi from NUS Enterprise: agustiadi@nus.edu.sg
events.location: Seminar Room 3, Town Plaza, UTown, NUS

events.name: TGIFHacks #49 - node.JS
events.description:
node.JS is an open source, cross-platform runtime environment for server-side JavaScript applications used in many web applications today. It is part of the extremely popular MEAN stack. This workshop will introduce the basics of node.JS after a quick run of JavaScript.

Come down and learn more about node.JS! For this workshop, you simply have to bring your laptops!

events.name: DataScience SG Mar Meetup - Microsoft
events.description:
For this meetup, Microsoft will be sharing with us their work on IoT and Smart City as well as their analytics platforms, Azure ML, Revolution R and Cortana Analytics. Come to the meetup to find out what they have been working on and what they have to offer! 


Housekeeping • Please refer to the new attendance policy before RSVP to this meetup. • RSVP will only open on 11th Mar, Friday (12pm) and closes on 16th Mar, Wednesday (12pm). • Due to necessary security clearance to enter Microsoft office, registration is necessary for attendance. 



Event Details 6:45 pm-7:15 pm: IT set up, registration, food enjoyment, networking 7:15 pm – 8:00 pm: Lesly Goh, Director of Advanced Analytics, Microsoft Toward Maturity in the Smart City Ecosystem [casual] Highlights of IoT and Advanced Analytics project, outcomes to date and insights/implications for changes in social, infrastructural and service dimensions.  Preview of IoT Asia Conference Session 8:00 pm – 8:15 pm: Networking and Refreshment Break 8:15 pm – 8:45 pm: Fang Zhou, Data Scientist, Microsoft Microsoft Advanced Analytics and Big Data [casual] Microsoft advanced analytics and big data solution, introduce Azure ML and Revolution R (SQL R Services/Microsoft R Server), demonstrate could/on-premises solutions on flight delay prediction. 8:45 pm – 9:15 pm: Yijing Chen, Data Scientist II, Microsoft Building End-to-End Advanced Analytics Solution on Cortana Analytics [casual] Advanced analytics solution building process, introduce Microsoft Cortana Analytics and demonstrate an end-to-end solution on energy demand forecast. 9:15 pm – 9:30 pm: Wrap-up [casual] 


[] : Suggested rating and topic; ranges from: newbie - casual - core - hardcore. 



Housekeeping • Please refer to the new attendance policy before RSVP to this meetup. • RSVP will only open on 11th Mar, Friday (12pm) and closes on 16th Mar, Wednesday (12pm). • Due to necessary security clearance to enter Microsoft office, registration is necessary for attendance.

events.name: Open data ideas with OpenData ASEAN
events.description:
We are doing a different kind of meetup this time round to focus on open data ideas for social impact analysis. Do come prepared with an idea (see pitching guidelines below) or come ready to join a team to work on open data. We will work together with successfully formed teams to develop their data analysis ideas, and match with non-profit organizations which can benefit from this analysis! Schedule 6.45 - 7pm: Registration (no food/drinks will be served, so do grab a bite beforehand) 7 - 7.45pm: Mishari Muqbil of OpenData ASEAN will be presenting on open data initiatives, followed by Q&A 7.45 - 8.15pm: Come forward to pitch your open data ideas (2 min each) 8.15 - 8.45pm: Form teams to work on different open data ideas 8.45 - 9pm: Register your teams with DataKind SG, and arrange follow-ups for teams to work on successful open data ideas! 


What ideas are we looking for?  Here are some guidelines:  • Is it a DataKind focus area? Poverty, Health, Environment, Education, Human Rights, Urban issues. • How much impact? Hint: bigger is better… • Can it be measured? • Is there an organization or government that can carry it further - think promotion, human resources, scaling up, etc. • Is the idea paradigm shifting (a faster horse versus a car) • What is the probability of success? • What is the likelihood for the analysis to yield meaningful results? • What is the likelihood for the organization to carry out the action? • What is the likelihood for action to lead to a positive impact? Formulate an impact statement for your pitch We are looking for impactful ideas! Try to formulate an impact statement for your pitch in the following format: Use [an open data set] in order to [type of analysis] so that[an organization] can [an organizational action] that leads to [an impact on issue] E.g. DC Action for Children: Use [child wellbeing data] in order to [create a map-based visualization] so that [DC Action for Children] can [make findings accessible to policymakers] that leads to [policy improvements in child well-being in DC]  Pitching guidelines • Identify the social impact area you want to analyze, and possible beneficiary non-profit organizations (see "What ideas are we looking for?" above) • Look for open data sets as well as existing data research/analysis, in the identified social impact area • Think of what you hope to analyze/mash up, and what kind of skills you might need in your team to do this e.g. web scrapping, machine learning • Condense your idea to a 2 minute pitch including an impact statement (see "Formulate an impact statement for your pitch" above), and you're all set! 


Possible Open Data Ideas • United Nations Millennium Development Goals (MDG)http://mdgs.un.org/unsd/mdg/Default.aspx • World Bank Open Datahttp://data.worldbank.org/ • Open Data Institute Guides http://theodi.org/guides • Open Development Mekong https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/ • Singapore’s Open Data portal https://data.gov.sg/ • Philippine's Open Data portal  http://data.gov.ph/  



Speaker Profile Mishari has been an enthusiastic fan of the potential of data ever since he read his first copy of "Freakonomics". Now he evangelizes the virtues of data and data driven decision making to anyone who cares to listen (and many who don't) and is highly enthusiastic of the potentials of data driven discourse in our society. He's also the CEO of a Boutique web hosting company, Proteus Operations.
events.location: #03-04, IDA labs @ National Design Centre,  #03-04, 111 Middle Road, 188969, Singapore

events.name: [Benjamin Ang & Cosmic Armchair] Digital Dondang Sayang
events.description:
Presented by NUS Centre For The Arts
with Benjamin Ang, Cosmic Armchair and the NUS Electronic Music Lab
Fri & Sat 18 & 19 Mar | 8pm | NUS Baba House | $12
Discounts & concessions available at bit.ly/CFATIX

Electronic musician Benjamin Ang - producer / keyboardist from electronic pop duo Cosmic Armchair and principal tutor of NUS Electronic Music Lab - embarks on a journey to discover his musical roots, through a collection of pantun (poems) composed by his Peranakan great-grandfather Ang Kay Teong. From the stack of yellowed papers etched with lyrics composed almost a century ago emerges a cosmic link between these poet/musicians, born three generations apart.

[About Benjamin Ang]
Benjamin Ang first joined the NUS Electronic Music Lab (EML) - the performance group based at the NUS Centre for the Arts that composes, performs and promotes electronic music - when he was a student in NUS Law School. Because he never left, he was appointed the tutor of the EML in 1999 and principal tutor in 2001. He has brought NUS EML through performances and installations at The Esplanade, Waterfront and Concourse. The Substation, NUS University Cultural Centre, Zouk Club, The Arts House, and the Hong Kong City Festival.
